caption:
Table 1: Basic statistics of the WSJ dataset. #Docs 
represents the number of original articles and #Syn-
thetic Docs represents the number of original articles 
and their permuted versions.

Table 2: Basic statistics of the GCDC dataset. For 
each of these domains, a fixed split of 1000 and 200 
was used for train and test respectively as specified in 
[Lai and Tetreault, 2018]. NC=Non-coherent, L=low, 
M=medium, H=High.

Table 3: Basic statistics of the GCDC dataset for the 
sentence ordering task. We used the same train and test 
split as specified in
Table 4: Sentence ordering task PRA results on WSJ

Table 5: Sentence ordering PRA results on GCDC. 
"(all)" indicates that training data across all four do-
mains was used.

Table 6: 3-way classification accuracy results on 
GCDC. "(all)" indicates that training data across all 
four domains was used.

Table 7: Coherence Score Spearman correlation Pre-
diction results on GCDC. "(all)" indicates that training 
data across all four domains was used.
